Text: Why do you boast of evil, O mighty man? The loving devotion of God endures all day long.
Context: This verse confronts the proud and arrogant behavior of the mighty man, contrasting it with God’s enduring loving devotion.

Text: Your tongue devises destruction like a sharpened razor, O worker of deceit.
Context: The verse graphically describes the power of the tongue to cause harm, likening it to a sharpened tool used by a deceitful person.

Text: You love evil rather than good, falsehood rather than speaking the truth.
column7: The verse describes the wicked person‘s perverse preference for evil and falsehood, calling for contemplation (Selah).

Text: You love every word that devours, O deceitful tongue.
Context: This verse continues the theme of the destructive power of speech, emphasizing the malicious intent behind the words.

Text: But God will tear you down forever; He will snatch you up and pluck you from your tent; He will uproot you from the land of the living.
column7: The verse switches perspective, assuring that God will bring justice against the wicked.

Text: The righteous will see and fear; they will laugh at him, saying,
Context: The response of the righteous is prophesied. They will witness God’s justice upon the wicked and react accordingly.

Text: Here is the man who did not make God his stronghold, but trusted in his great wealth and strengthened himself by destroying others.
Context: This verse is a derisive epitaph for the destroyer, emphasizing his misplaced trust in wealth and power.

Text: But I am like an olive tree flourishing in the house of God; I trust in the loving devotion of God forever and ever.
Context: The psalmist contrasts himself with the wicked, expressing steadfast trust and confidence in God‘s everlasting love, using the metaphor of a flourishing olive tree.

Text: I will praise You forever for what You have done; in the presence of Your saints I will wait on Your name— for it is good.
Context: The psalm concludes with a declaration of praise and a resolve to wait on God, suggesting a communal setting among the saints.
